abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is rated
            unsatisfactory, sustainability unlikely, yet institutional
            development impacts were modest, but both the Bank and
            Borrower performances are rated unsatisfactory. Lessons
            reinforce that project design should be simplified, focused,
            and include only organically-linked components. The
            inclusion of other components is likely to result in the
            neglect or mismanagement of some of the components. This
            project covered the whole country and included slum
            improvements, municipal service provision, infrastructure
            for new municipalities, a municipal loan scheme, and a
            microfinance scheme. The attention paid to each of these
            sub-components varied considerably, to the extent that the
            municipal loan scheme was virtually abandoned, though never
            formally closed. The project involved a wide range of
            institutions, which not all did share the same priorities in
            relation to the project objectives. Moreover, a
            decentralized approach requires a strong commitment of all
            stakeholders, and, the responsibilities of each institution
            involved in the implementation of the project have to be
            clearly distributed. Further lessons address the critical
            aspect of periodic technical audits, and the need for
            supporting measures in terms of management of facilities and
            maintenance, needed to accompany investments programs.

18153188.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Urban development

abstracts.cdata!:
In line with the Country Assistance
            Strategy, the Municipal Support Project will: a) improve
            welfare in urban areas by increasing urban incomes and
            improving urban services; b) improve incomes and living
            conditions of low income groups in urban areas; c) improve
            the ability of the national and local governments to sustain
            urban services over time by establishing improved systems
            for financing and managing urban services; d) contribute to
            sustainable municipal development through environmental
            improvement and protection. The project consists of two main
            components: i) priority urban works, including minimum
            infrastructure for small municipalities; pilot operations in
            squatter settlements to be developed into a rehabilitation
            program for low-income areas; revenue-earning investments
            (markets, bus terminals etc); and ii) municipal capacity
            building, through training and support to Mission
            d'Appui a la Conduite d'Operations Municipales
            (MACOM); improvement of the mobilization of local resources;
            and support to the informal sector.
